issue.title: [ENH]: Add a Simple Moving Average Forecaster to the time series module.

labels.name: time_series
labels.description: Topics related to the time series

repository.name: pycaret
repository.description: An open-source, low-code machine learning library in Python

issue.body:
### Describe the feature you want to add to this project

Add a Simple Moving Average Forecaster to the time series module.

### Describe your proposed solution

See starting point for solution here: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3992
More work is needed through since this is not working completely.

### Describe alternatives you've considered, if relevant

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

body:
Re moving average:

You can get moving average as a special case of ARIMA, by switching off the AR and I parts. MA stands for moving average.

Use any of the ARIMA models in `sktime` with `p=0` and `d=0`. The `q` parameter determines the order of the moving average. More precisely, ARIMA (0, 0, q) = MA(q).
Re reducer: it seems there may be something wrong, possibly a bug. FYI @danbartl. Will also have a look.

> You can get moving average as a special case of ARIMA, by switching off the AR and I parts. MA stands for moving average.
> 
> Use any of the ARIMA models in `sktime` with `p=0` and `d=0`. The `q` parameter determines the order of the moving average. More precisely, ARIMA (0, 0, q) = MA(q).

Hi @fkiraly , This may not work for 2 reasons.

1. ARIMA MA part relies on model errors from past points and not the raw y values ([Ref](https://otexts.com/fpp3/MA.html)).
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33585645/209449355-b16be36c-5d49-4ead-93da-affcd067ea57.png)

Hence, after crossing future points > q, it will not be able to predict ([Link to Code](https://gist.github.com/ngupta23/4aaab9205ef3de3921c3a5a580f7701d)). 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33585645/209449181-f753c180-de06-4fd6-b277-1a6a9e886c4e.png)

2. Even if it was working,, it does not provide any control over the coefficients of the model so the past 'q' points would be weighted differently (theta values in the equation above) depending on how the model gets fitted.

I am looking for a Simple Moving Average where all past q points are weighted equally. This would be a starting (baseline) model, then I would add additional complexity on top of that iteratively to see what helps to improve the model. This could include for example, building more features beyond a simple moving average (e.g. lags, standard deviations, mins, max, etc) or changing out the regressor to more complex ones so see if they help. Hence, a working baseline solution using regressors would be helpful to have. 

Thanks!
oh, I see - you want an *equal weighted moving average* that is recursively applied?

> oh, I see - you want an _equal weighted moving average_ that is recursively applied?

Yes, a simple Moving Average, similar to `pd.rolling(ma_window).mean()`, but applied recursively to the forecasts as far out into the future as needed.

>but applied recursively to the forecasts as far out into the future as needed.

Well, it will converge to a constant if you go too far in the future...

> Well, it will converge to a constant if you go too far in the future...

It may, but I think only if all the values in a future Moving Average window are the same value. It would be based on pure luck or due to the choice of a very small MA window.

In any case, what I meant by "as far out into the future as needed" was not that we would necessarily be looking at long horizons, but something reasonable from the business need point of view.

> It may, but I think only if all the values in a future Moving Average window are the same value. It would be based on pure luck or due to the choice of a very small MA window.

No, I think: it always will, for all lengths of MA windows, and all values of the series, eventually.

Proof sketch: let $m$ be the window length, and $a_1, \dots, a_m$ be the last $m$ values of the series. Let $a_{m+1}, \dots$ be the future values obtained recursively through the recurrence relation $a_j := \frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^q a_{j-i}$.

The recurrence is linear, so you have $(a_{1+n}, \dots, a_{m+n}) = A^n \cdot (a_1, \dots, a_m)$ for the $(m \times m)$ square matrix which has $\frac{1}{m}$ in the last row, otherwise zeros in the first column, and the rest is an identity matrix (ones on the off-diagonal and zeros otherwise).

This is a special Toeplitz matrix or a special convolution matrix, which can be verified to have one eigenvalue 1, and the remaining eigenvalues are possibly complex but norm strictly smaller than one.
(for a full proof, this needs to be worked out)

The asmyptotic value ends up being interesting:
$\frac{1\cdot a_1 + \dots + m \cdot a_m}{1 + \dots + m}$,
i.e., the weighted mean of the original $a_i$ where the weight of $a_i$ is the integer $i$.

> No, I think: it always will, for all lengths of MA windows, and all values of the series, eventually.

The key there is "eventually". For long horizons, that is correct (similar to what ARMA models would produce). But for short horizons, they can still produce reasonable baseline results. The key there is the selection of an appropriate window size (not too short as that can result in constant forecasts even in the short term). The definition of "short term" of course is business dependent and will vary based on frequency of data (monthly vs. weekly) and so will the appropriate selection of the MA window size.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33585645/209472450-3d10c80b-4d58-47f8-bfce-03dd5aa3c850.png)

But I think we are digressing from the original intent of this request. I would like to see if this capability can be implemented with the reduced regression setting in sktime today. It would be very helpful for my use case.

Thanks!

I think what you need to do with the present framework is to use a different tabular predictor, namely the hard coded linear model that averages:

```python
class AverageX(BaseEstimator):
    def fit(self, X, y):
        X, y = check_X_y(X, y, accept_sparse=True)
        self.is_fitted_ = True
        # `fit` should always return `self`
        return self

    def predict(self, X):
        X = check_array(X, accept_sparse=True)
        check_is_fitted(self, "is_fitted_")
        # Returns the first column
        return X.mean(axis=1)
```

Then, using recursive reduction:
```python
make_reduction(
    estimator=AverageX(),
    scitype="tabular-regressor",
    window_length=whatever_you_want,
    strategy="recursive",                
),
```
Thanks @fkiraly. I will try it out and let you know how it goes.
